subject: Re: [junit] Compiling and running a Junit Test
msgSnippet: John, I don t believe the Windows version looks at the %CLASSPATH% environment variable, but I may be wrong (not really a Windows guy).  Also, there is no
messageBody:
John,

I don't believe the Windows version looks at the %CLASSPATH% environment
variable, but I may be wrong (not really a Windows guy). Also, there is
no package called junit. There is junit.extensions and junit.framework
-- IOW, there are no source files in junit/ for you to import, so you
can take that out of your source file.

Try the following commandline after you remove "import junit.*" from
your source:
javac -cp c:\junit\junit.jar -d object source\*.java

The other thing is that it would be worth your while picking up Ant and
building (and even running tests) that way. See
http://jakarta.apache.org/ant

=jason

On Wed, 2002-07-17 at 16:26, john60515 wrote: Hi,

I'm a computer science student having problems compiling and running
my junit Test file. Can anyone help?

My regular java files compile. I have the source code in c:\jdk1.3
\myproject\source and the .class files in c:\jdk1.3\myproject\object.
I have also put the junit test .java file in the 'source' directory.

Junit is downloaded and extracted in c:\junit Both the unzipped
files and the junit.jar file is in this directory.

The system classpath is set to
c:\junit;c:\junit\junit.jar;c:\junit\junit\framework
and my Test file has
import junit.*;
import junit.framework.*;

With command
c:\jdk1.3\myProject>javac -d object source\*.java

the error messages are saying that packages junit and junit.framework
do not exist.

Any ideas?

Thanks,
John
